citations.narrative:
On Sunday, May 18, 2025, while exhibiting at a private party event in Encino, CA, Indy, an adult M Rose-Ringed Parakeet
(aka Indian Ringneck Parakeet), took flight to a nearby tree. The licensee stated that Indy flew to and landed in several
trees near the residence and surrounding yards, but he did not return despite considerable and prolonged capture efforts.
Escaped exotic bird species face many challenges, including predation, to survival in the wild. At the time of the
inspection, Indy was still missing.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Corrected on June 5, 2025, and forward.

Kahlua, an adult FS Great Pyrenees mix, DOB (~2016), was found on inspection to be overdue for her rabies vaccine
(last given on 7-20-2021) and other vaccines, (DHPPV & Bordetella last given on 12-7-2022). Her last Heartworm (HW)
check was not documented, and her last fecal examination was overdue (done on 6-30-2023).
Brock, an adult MN Pyrenees, DOB 4-25-2016, was overdue for his HW test and fecal (last done on 6-30-2023).
Buddy, a MN Pyrenees mix, DOB 5-14-2023, was overdue for DHLPP (last given on 10-23-2023), and Bordetella (last
given on 3-29-2024). He was overdue for his HW and fecal test.
Xena, a F Pyrenees mix acquired on 7-31-2024, was overdue for her HW and fecal test.
Current vaccination status is important to maintain immunity from diseases that affect dogs. Heartworm and intestinal
parasite testing is important to determine whether or not dogs have parasites that can pose a significant threat to their
health and well-being, and to select what parasiticides are appropriate for their treatment and/or prevention.
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly
diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests
(including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with the schedule approved by the attending
veterinarian.
Corrected on June 6, 2025, and forward.

There were no recorded dates or results for annual heartworm testing or fecal/intestinal parasite testing within a 12-month
period (as written in the program for veterinary care) for 4 dogs at the time of the inspection. From the records provided
later, it appeared that all 4 dogs were overdue for these tests. Two of the dogs were overdue for their vaccinations. And
there were no medical records provided that documented their required annual physical exams. Documentation of
required tests and examinations is important to record and relay important health information to ensure optimum animal
health and treatments needed and/or given.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available
for APHIS inspection. These records must include (in part): The dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or
other required or recommended tests or examinations.
Corrected on June 6, 2025, and forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with an authorized person.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On Sunday, May 18, 2025, while exhibiting at a private party event in Encino, CA, Indy, an adult M Rose-Ringed Parakeet 
(aka Indian Ringneck Parakeet), took flight to a nearby tree. The licensee stated that Indy flew to and landed in several 
trees near the residence and surrounding yards, but he did not return despite considerable and prolonged capture efforts. 
Escaped exotic bird species face many challenges, including predation, to survival in the wild. At the time of the 
inspection, Indy was still missing. 
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public.  
 
Corrected on June 5, 2025, and forward. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Kahlua, an adult FS Great Pyrenees mix, DOB (~2016), was found on inspection to be overdue for her rabies vaccine 
(last given on 7-20-2021) and other vaccines, (DHPPV & Bordetella last given on 12-7-2022). Her last Heartworm (HW) 
check was not documented, and her last fecal examination was overdue (done on 6-30-2023). 
 
Brock, an adult MN Pyrenees, DOB 4-25-2016, was overdue for his HW test and fecal (last done on 6-30-2023). 
 
Buddy, a MN Pyrenees mix, DOB 5-14-2023, was overdue for DHLPP (last given on 10-23-2023), and Bordetella (last 
given on 3-29-2024). He was overdue for his HW and fecal test. 
 
Xena, a F Pyrenees mix acquired on 7-31-2024, was overdue for her HW and fecal test. 
 
Current vaccination status is important to maintain immunity from diseases that affect dogs. Heartworm and intestinal 
parasite testing is important to determine whether or not dogs have parasites that can pose a significant threat to their

health and well-being, and to select what parasiticides are appropriate for their treatment and/or prevention.  
 
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is 
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly 
diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests 
(including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with the schedule approved by the attending 
veterinarian. 
 
Corrected on June 6, 2025, and forward. 
3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There were no recorded dates or results for annual heartworm testing or fecal/intestinal parasite testing within a 12-month 
period (as written in the program for veterinary care) for 4 dogs at the time of the inspection. From the records provided 
later, it appeared that all 4 dogs were overdue for these tests. Two of the dogs were overdue for their vaccinations. And 
there were no medical records provided that documented their required annual physical exams. Documentation of 
required tests and examinations is important to record and relay important health information to ensure optimum animal 
health and treatments needed and/or given.  
 
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available 
for APHIS inspection. These records must include (in part): The dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or 
other required or recommended tests or examinations. 
 
Corrected on June 6, 2025, and forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with an authorized person.
